If anyone’s wondering what a 4D object or a 5D object looks like, Think of it this way. A 2D corner is where multiple 1D lines intersect, and a 3D corner is where multiple 2D shapes intersect. This means a 4D corner is where multiple 3D shapes intersect, but they don’t merge. They are inside each other, while staying seperate objects. So now imagine a full 4D shape. Now imagine multiple of those intersecting. That is a 5D corner. This pattern continues forever

To all the people in the comments that are confused about how we can only be in a 1D world curled up to look 3D but it may as well be curled up into 2D, or how we can traverse this 3D world so many different ways instead of being constrained to a 1D path. This video explains dimensions WRONG. A 1D world cannot curl up on itself in if there is only 1 direction to move along. A string would not bend if it was constrained to one direction of motion. Multiple dimensions are constituted of multiple orthogonal direction vectors. This means that each measurement of spacial direction must be 90 degrees from each other so that neither one involves another. If we are all living on a 1D line of space that is curled up then, A) There must be 3 dimensional directions available in space for the line to curl up though. or B) There must be multiple 1D lines connected all points along our 1D line so that we can take free form paths to get from one point to another instead of being constrained in every potential motion.

A curled up line: By Euclidian geometry, that is a contradiction in terms. Thus, other geometries have to be used, yes. But its not just that simple. A "curled up line" by itself will violate rules depending on which set you use. I would assume that the system of dimensions was originally conceived based on Euclidean geometry, so it could be considered a part of the definition.

What about the homotopy group's? In fact we know that 1D (R1), 2D (R2) and 3D (R3) are not topologically the same thing. For example the real line R is not homeomorphic to the plane R2, the prove goes as follows: suppose there were a homeomorphism h of R onto R2. Select some point x0 e R. The restriction of h to R-(x0) would then carry it homeomorphically onto R2-(h[x0]). However, R-(x0) is not connected, whereas R2-(h[x0]) certainly is connected . Since connectedness is a topological property, this cannot be and we have our contradiction. We can use a similar argumet between R2 and R3, R3 is simply connected and R2 is not. 
   Think now in a point electric charge "q" residing at the origin of some intertial frame of reference. The electric field E satisfy the static, source-free maxwell equations divE=0, curlE=0 (idem with B) in R3-(0,0,0) . Because of the “simply connectedness” property of R3 we can guarantee the existence of a scalar potencial function whose gradient is E and solve the problem, therefore electromagnetism and this kind of phenomena tells us information about the topology and dimension that could have the space.

Space filling curves aren't at all what you are saying. If you truly fill space (be it 2-D or 3-D) using only a 1D line, then for any points A and B in the curve, if you were to follow the line from A to B, you'd travel an infinite distance. So, it's not like we could use only one coordinate that would tell you the position in the line (and therefore in the space) you are at, all the points are infinitely distant from one another so there is no metric. You NEED more dimensions to fully describe the space.

What you CAN argue is that you can do an approximation of a space filling curve. A 1-D line that does not pass through every point in space, but that passes nearby every point in space. And by nearby i mean that the shortest distance from any point in space to that line is always smaller than the Planck's length. Then, you could argue that you can describe 3-D space using only one coordinate, because any distance smaller than the Plank's length doesn't make much sense, and therefore, as far as your calculations are concerned, the line does pass through every point in space, and is 1-D.

For Emmanuel, try reading flatland or a book that describes the concepts discussed in flatland. A principal wrote it i think, and it is definitely aimed at simplifying the discussion. The basic crux of the book is that in a 2 dimensional world the creatures that exist would not be able to recognise a 3 dimensional object.
Simplest example, if a sphere passed through flat land it would start as a dot, keep getting bigger, reach its maximum diameter then start shrinking until just a dot remains, then nothing. Observing this outside of Flatland we see a dot become a circle, reach its maximum then shrink away to nothing. You're thinking along the right lines, but this is a flawed statement. The universe is actually curved. Imagine a flat, 2D universe. You can take that universe and curve it into a sphere, so that the universe is only in the sphere's surface, but it exists in three dimensions. In the same manner, a 1D universe can be twisted into a circle, or even a sphere if you wrap it around enough.

It can. Imagine a piece of paper with no depth. Fold it. It still has no depth. Fold it again. Still no depth. And yet, Calculus tells us that if we were to fold it an infinite number of times, that paper would have a finite depth, such as a foot, or a yard, or 2.763 lightyears. In the same manner, a single line could be wrapped around itself to create the illusion of a second and third dimension. In short, an infinite number of infinitesimals is finite. Basic Calculus.

In fact, dimension is a topological property (can be defined completely in terms of continuity) and is intrinsic to the space.

We can't actually "see" 4D objects, just as we can't really "see" 0D, 1D, or 2D "objects". A piece of paper looks flat and 2D, but it is really a 3D object (it has length, width, height. A line drawn on said paper looks line a single line (1D), but is really a residue of material with length, width, and height. Same goes for a point drawn on a piece of paper. We can only ever see "snapshots" of 4D objects at different points in their timeline, represented as 3D objects.

The 4th dimension is actually easy to explain:
- Consider a single point in space (0D).
- Track the movement of that point over a period of time. You get a line (1D).
- Track the movement of that line over a period of time. You get a 2D shape.
- Track the movement of that shape over a period of time. You get a 3D object.
- Track the movement of that object over a period of time. You get a 4D figure.

3-D video effects are just a trick of the light. The glasses you are wearing which make the video LOOK 3-D are refracting the light coming off the screen in such a way that when it hits your retina (the little black dot on your eye) it shifts the rays in 3 directions depending on the color being refracted. 

So basically when you look at a 3-D television your looking at 2-D and 3-D at the same time, because the screen is still 2-D, but the light coming off is in 3-D.

in fact, the Sierpinski curve (and lots of other space-filling curves) are indeed continuous maps of the circle into 2-space, but what this really shows is not that the statement is so amazing, but that the word "continuous" has a weaker meaning than you think. There seems to be a lot of misunderstanding here, so I'll try to clear some of it up: 

Time is not the 4th dimension, but the 4th dimension is not an unknown. Imagine a 4D cube (a tesseract) as two 3D cubes conjoined at the vertices. The link between these two 3D cubes is the next step after length, width, and height. Attempting to view a 4D cube from our 3D space is like trying to view a 3D cube from a 2D space. That is, you would only see one 2D slice of the cube at once.

He points out that there are alternatives, then says that if you want to describe how gasses diffuse, you better be using three dimensions! It's not so much a theory about what's out there, as an exercise in asking ourselves why we think about things in the way that we do.

@DoctorFastest One way to see a difference between the two things is to ask what predictions they make about how things should behave. Gasses spread out in the three normal direction, not along the weird direction that goes through every point. @SuperDoctor16 You exist in a four dimension reality.  You have height, width, depth, and the space you occupy has depth.  Your motion displaces some depth of space with your depth.  Your depth is limited in the same way your height and width are limited, but your motion is as limited as the space you exist in (imagine being stuck in some tight space compared to being in an open field). Suppose you can fly, an upward motion makes it impossible for you to motion left, right, back, forth or down.

There's NO SUCH THING as 3D! 3D is a perception of 4D. Reality exists in four dimensions. Mona Lisa can't step out of the painting to approach you, but you can step closer to the painting. If I record a video of you viewing the Mona Lisa the video is 3D, but it's an image of you viewing an image of the Mona Lisa; Images aren't reality. The video shows your image approaches the image of the Mona Lisa but the distance between the two images doesn't ~actually~ change because 3D has no ~real~ depth.
